# [Language]{style="background: black; color: white;"} acquisition ---



::: center **What** is language? ::: ::: center What is language **like**? ::: ::: center What is language **for**? ::: ::: center Where does language come **from**? ::: ## What is language?

No easy, complete, specific way to define language - **Complete**: captures *all* features of language - **Specific**: captures *only* features of language ## What is language? ::: center {{< video img/koko.mp4 title="Koko" start="120" width="800" >}} ::: ## What is language? ::: center {{< video img/alex.mp4 title="Alex" width="700" >}} ::: ## What is language?

### Language as an object Finite system of symbols (words) that can be combined using rules to make a virtually infinite number of distinct sentences. ## What is language? ::: center {{< video img/protactile.mp4 title="Protactile language" width="800" >}} ::: ## What is language? ::: center {{< video img/silbo-gomero.mp4 title="Silbo gomero" width="800" >}} ::: ## What is language? ::: center {{< video img/kus-dili.mp4 title="Kuş dili" width="800" >}} ::: ## What is language?

### Language as an object Finite system of [symbols]{style="background: black; color: white"} (words) that can be combined using rules to make a virtually infinite number of distinct sentences.
::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Words** (symbols, in general) hold **arbitrary** relationship between form and meaning^[With few exceptions]. Does the word *tree* sound, look, or feel like a tree? ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/tree.png){width=200} ::: ::: ::: ## What is language?

### Language as an object [Finite]{style="background: black; color: white"} system of symbols (words) that can be combined using rules to make a virtually infinite number of distinct sentences. ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="30%"} **Limited number of words** in a language. ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} |Person | Words | Lemmas | Base words | |-------------|---------|--------|------------| | *20-year-old* | | | | | Low end | 84,000 | 27,100 | 6,100 | | Median | | 42,000 | 11,100 | | High end | 292,000 | 51,700 | 14,900 | | *60-year-old* | | | | | Low end | 157,000 | 35,100 | 9,000 | | Median | | 48,200 | 13,400 | | High end | 543,000 | 56,400 | 16,700 | : Adapted from @brysbaert_how_2016. ::: ::: ## What is language?

### Language as an object Finite system of symbols (words) that can be combined using [rules]{style="background: black; color: white"} to make a virtually infinite number of distinct sentences.
::: {.columns} ::: {.column} Words (and other linguistic units) are **combined in systematic ways**, following rules we know as **grammar**. ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/recursivity.gif) ::: ::: ::: ## What is language?

### Language as an object 7,745 identified languages ([Glottolog](https://glottolog.org/)) | AES status | # of languages | % of languages | |----------------|----------------|----------------| | not endangered | 2643 | 34.13% | | threatened | 1595 | 20.59% | | shifting | 1805 | 23.31% | | moribund | 422 | 5.45% | | nearly extinct | 299 | 3.86% | | extinct | 981 | 12.67% | : Agglomerated Endangerment Status [@hammarstrom_glottologglottolog_2025] ## What is language?

### Language as a function [Ability]{style="background: black;color: white;"} to systematically combine (**grammar**) a finite set of symbols (**words**) provided by a language so that a virtually ilimited number of sentences can be created (**productivity**).
::: incremental * Can Koko combine signs **productively** to communicate complex ideas? * Can speakers of silbo gomero combine different whistles **productively**?
* Is Alex's communication **symbolic**? * Are tactile cues in protactile language **symbolic**? ::: ## What is language like? ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

Linguistics : Scientific study of language(s)
Languages are made of different **linguistic units**, which are **organised hierarchically**: ::: incremental * Phonemes * Syllables * Words * Sentences ::: ::: ::: {.column} [![](img/linguistics.png)](https://blogonlinguistics.wordpress.com/2016/03/26/what-is-linguistics/) ::: ::: ## What is language like?

::: center ![](img/meyer.jpg)[@meyer_neural_2018] ::: ## What is language like?

Phonemes : Speech sounds that distinguish words with different meaning in a particular language [International Phonology Association (IPA)](https://www.ipachart.com/) ::: incremental * In Catalan and Spanish, do **/d/ and /ð/** distinguish meanings? + Do /dedo/ and /deðo/ mean different things in Spanish? * In Catalan and Spanish, do **/o/ and /ɔ/** distinguish meanings? + Do /os/ and /ɔs/ mean different things in Catalan? And in Spanish? ::: ## What is language like?

Phonemes : Speech sounds that distinguish words with different meaning. ::: {.callout-caution title="Phonemes ≠ Letters"} casa [Catalan for *house*] : 4 letters, 4 phonemes: /k a z a/ cotxe [Catalan for *car*] : 5 letters, 4 phonemes: /k o t͡ʃ ə/ ::: ## What is language like? ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

Syllables : Minimal unit of pronunciation. Universal structure! ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/syllable.png) ::: ::: ::: ## What is language like? ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

Words : Form-meaning association (minimal unit of meaning).
Mental lexicon : "Mental dictionary" that contains information about the form, meaning, and grammatical function of every word know by a person. ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/word-forms.png) ::: ::: ::: ## What is language like?

|Person | Words | Lemmas | Base words | |-------------|---------|--------|------------| | *20-year-old* | | | | | Low end | 84,000 | 27,100 | 6,100 | | Median | | 42,000 | 11,100 | | High end | 292,000 | 51,700 | 14,900 | | *60-year-old* | | | | | Low end | 157,000 | 35,100 | 9,000 | | Median | | 48,200 | 13,400 | | High end | 543,000 | 56,400 | 16,700 | : Adapted from @brysbaert_how_2016. ## What is language like? ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

Sentence : Words organised into grammatically coherent structures. Maximal unit of speech production. **Grammar** provides the **rules** that allow speakers of a language to combine words in a **productive** way, to express virtually any possible meaning. ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/syntax.png) ::: ::: ::: ## What is language for?

::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Language as a tool for *communication***
The ability for complex thinking provided humans with the ability to learn language [@fedorenko_language_2024; @hockett1960origin; @kirby2008cumulative]. Complex thinking does not necessarily engage language-related brain areas and vice versa (double dissociation) [@fedorenko_language_2024] ::: ::: {.column} **Language as a tool for *thinking***
The ability to use language provided humans with complex thinking [@chomsky2014minimalist; @goldin2003thought]. Some forms of thinking require or are facilitated by language [e.g., @lupyan_language_2007] ::: ::: ## Where does language come from?

Symbolic communication appears between 1,000,000 and 100,000 years ago (*Homo erectus*) [@barham_semiotics_2021].
::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Why? How?** Two approaches: * Language "appears" [@berwick2016only; @chomsky2014minimalist] * Language develops [@tomasello2003constructing; @christiansen2003language] ::: ::: {.column} Can only be investigated *indirectly*: - Sparse archaeological evidence - Cultural transmission and evolution - Evolutionary biology ::: ::: # Language [acquisition]{style="background: black;color: white;"} ## Is language *learned*?

::: {.incremental} * Humans need **exposure** to language to acquire language * Not all humans speak the same language, and genes do not explain cross-linguistic differences * There is an obvious learning component to language acquisition ::: ## Is language *inherited*?

::: {.incremental} * Language acquisition is **efficient**: Humans acquire their native language(s) in little time, without effort, and without explicit instruction * **Stimulus poverty**: language cannot be possible learned from experience alone (lack of positive and negative evidence) * Language is **unique to humans**, non-human animals do not acquire language even after intensive training ::: ## Current directions

Which aspects are more **experience dependent**? **Which experience** do they depend on? Which **mechanisms** underlie language learning? To what extent do humans share these mechanisms with **other species**? # Before-birth Pre-natal language exposure ## Fetal auditory development ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

* The fetal auditory system is **functional from 20 weeks of gestation** * **Biological tissues** (skin, muscle, amniotic liquid) filter the acoustic signal * **Low-pass filter**: frequencies lower than 550 Hz reach the fetus' ears, higher frequencies do not ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![@hepper_development_1994](img/fetal-hearing.png){fig-align="right"} ::: ::: ::: ## Fetal language exposure ### Acoustics in the womb ::: center {{< video img/womb.mp4 title="Acoustics in the womb" width="800" >}} ::: ## Fetal language exposure ### Acoustics in the womb

::: {.columns} ::: {.column} * The fetal auditory system is **functional from 20 weeks of gestation** * **Biological tissues** (skin, muscle, amniotic liquid) filter the acoustic signal * **Low-pass filter**: frequencies lower than 550 Hz reach the fetus' ears, higher frequencies do not ::: ::: {.column} ::: center Low-pass filtered signal ::: ::: {#1177c5dd .cell execution_count=2} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ::: center Original signal ::: ::: {#93268288 .cell execution_count=3} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ::: center High-pass filtered signal ::: ::: {#f7acf417 .cell execution_count=4} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Fetal language exposure * Fetus' get familiarized with prosodic features of their native language(s) + **Intonation**: modulation of the frequency of speech sounds across segments + **Rhythm**: rate at which linguistic units are produce per unit of time * Still quite **unfamiliar with segmental information** (i.e., different consonants) ## Fetal language exposure ::: box **Auditory learning** is already present at 33 gestational weeks. ::: **DeCasper et al. (1994)** ::: incremental * 28 pregnant women in their 33 gestational week recited a poem 3 consecutive times per day for 4 weeks. * At test, fetuses auditory stimulated with [familiar poem]{style="background: black;color: white"} or an [unfamiliar poem]{style="background: grey;color: white"} (control). * Beat-to-beat intervals of the fetal heart were recorded (doppler cardiotocograph). * The [familiar poem]{style="background: black;color: white"} decreased heartbeat rate, the [unfamiliar poem]{style="background: grey;color: white"} did not. ::: # 0-6 months of age ## First encounters with language ::: box Newborns prefer speech over non-speech sounds. ::: **Vouloumanos, Christophe, and Bertoncini (1997)** ## First encounters with language **Vouloumanos, Christophe, and Bertoncini (1997)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} High Amplitude Sucking (HAS) procedure [@floccia_high-amplitude_1997] * Newborns are trained to **increase their sucking rate** in order to continue listening to some auditory stimulus. * Sucking rate is compared for two or more types of stimuli. * If newborns **prefer** some type of stimuli over the others, sucking rate should be higher for that type of stimulus. ::: ::: {.column} ::: ::: ## First encounters with language ::: center {{< video img/sucking.mp4 title="High Amplitude Sucking (HAS) procedure" width="800" >}} ::: ## First encounters with language **Vouloumanos, Christophe, and Bertoncini (1997)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} High Amplitude Sucking (HAS) procedure [@floccia_high-amplitude_1997] * Newborns are trained to **increase their sucking rate** in order to continue listening to some auditory stimulus. * Sucking rate is compared for two or more types of stimuli. * If newborns **prefer** some type of stimuli over the others, sucking rate should be higher for that type of stimulus. ::: ::: {.column}

::: center ![](img/voloumanos.png) ::: ::: ::: ## Language discrimination ::: box Newborns can discriminate between languages from different rhythm classes ::: **Nazzi et al. (1998)** ## Language discrimination

::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} | Rhythm group | Examples | | |------------------|------------------|---------------| | [*Syllable-timed*]{style="background:blue;color:white;"} | Catalan, Spanish | H O N - D A | | [*Stress-timed*]{style="background:red;color:white;"} | English, Dutch | H O N ~D~ ~A~ | | [*Mora-timed*]{style="background:green;color:white;"} | Japanese, Tamil | H O - N - D A | ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: center ![@ramus_correlates_1999](img/ramus.gif) ::: ::: ::: ## Language discrimination **Nazzi et al. (1998)** * Presented newborns with low-pass filtered sentences produced by natural speakers (keeping prosodic but not segmental information) * Sentences belonged to a [stress-timed]{style="background:red;color:white;"} language(English, Dutch) or a [mora-timed]{style="background:green;color:white;"} language (Japanese) ## Language discrimination **Nazzi et al. (1998)** English ([stress-timed]{style="background:red;color:white;"}) vs. Japanese ([mora-timed]{style="background:green;color:white;"}) ::: center ![](img/nazzi-1.png){width="65%"} ::: ## Language discrimination **Nazzi et al. (1998)** English ([stress-timed]{style="background:red;color:white;"}) vs. Dutch ([stress-timed]{style="background:red;color:white;"}) ::: center ![](img/nazzi-2.png){width="65%"} ::: ## (Bilingual) language discrimination ::: box Bilingual infants discriminate their native languages, even if they belong to the same rhythmic group. ::: **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2001)** ## (Bilingual) language discrimination ::: box Bilingual infants discriminate their native languages, even if they belong to the same rhythmic group. ::: **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2001)** Three groups of participants: * 4 month-old **Catalan monolinguals** * 4 month-old **Spanish monolinguals** * 4 month-old **Catalan-Spanish bilinguals** ## (Bilingual) language discrimination **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2001)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} **Familiarization-preference Procedure** [@jusczyk_infants_1995] 1) *Familiarization phase*: sentences in the native/dominant language 2) *Test phase*: sentences in both languages Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) language discrimination **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2001)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} **Familiarization-preference Procedure** [@jusczyk_infants_1995] 1) *Familiarization phase*: sentences in the native/dominant language 2) *Test phase*: sentences in both languages Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: center **Monolinguals** ::: ![](img/bosch-1.png) ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) language discrimination **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2001)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} **Familiarization-preference Procedure** [@jusczyk_infants_1995] 1) *Familiarization phase*: sentences in the native/dominant language 2) *Test phase*: sentences in both languages Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: center **Bilinguals** ::: ![](img/bosch-2.png) ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) language discrimination ![@nacar_garcia_evoked_2018](img/nacar.png) # 6-12 months of age ## Perceptual narrowing ::: box From 6 to 12 months of age, infants attune their perceptual abilities to the sounds of their native language. ::: **Werker and Tees (1984)** ## Perceptual narrowing **Werker and Tees (1984)** Three groups of participants exposed to exemplars of the /k/-/q/ consonant contrast [@mayes1979acoustic]: * 6 month-old infants * English native adults * Thompson (*Nlaka'pamuctsin*, native American) native adults ## Perceptual narrowing **Werker and Tees (1984)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"}

**/k̓/** → k̓ʔés [nostalgia] [{{< fa play >}}](https://www.firstvoices.com/nlekepmxcin/words/285cb131-85b5-4959-94d1-2fddda004e15) **/q̓/** → q̓ip̓éw̓stn [belt] [{{< fa play >}}](https://www.firstvoices.com/nlekepmxcin/words/861c1061-4606-4062-b54c-11397f5b2b61) ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: center ![](img/thompson.png) ::: ::: ::: ## Perceptual narrowing **Werker and Tees (1984)** ::: center ![](img/werker.png){width="50%" fig-align="center"} ::: ## Perceptual narrowing **Werker and Tees (1984)** {{< video img/hpp.mp4 title="Headturn Preference Procedure (HPP)" width="800" >}} ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing ::: box Perceptual narrowing also happens in bilinguals, but is evidenced in different ways than in monolinguals. ::: **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2003)** ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2003)** Three groups of infants: * 4.5 month-old **Catalan monolinguals** * 4.5 month-old **Spanish monolinguals** * 4.5 month-old **Catalan/Spanish bilinguals** ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2003)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="35%"} *Familiarization-preference procedure* 1) Familiarization phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *or* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ 2) Test phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *and* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column} ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2003)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="35%"} *Familiarization-preference procedure* 1) Familiarization phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *or* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ 2) Test phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *and* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column width="65%"} ![](img/bosch-2003-1.png) ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Bosch and Sebastian-Galles (2003)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="35%"} *Familiarization-preference procedure* 1) Familiarization phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *or* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ 2) Test phase: /d**e**ð̞i/ *and* /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ Which sentences do infants prefer to listen to? ::: ::: {.column width="65%"} ![](img/bosch-2003-2.png) ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing ::: box Perceptual narrowing also happens in bilinguals, but is evidenced in different ways than in monolinguals. ::: **Albareda-Castellot, Pons and Sebastian-Galles (2010)** Can Catalan/Spanish bilinguals really not discriminate the native, Catalan contrast? ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Albareda-Castellot, Pons and Sebastian-Galles (2010)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} **Anticipatory eye movement paradigm** Eye-tracking Can infants anticipate the trajectory of an object based on its associated speech sounds? E.g.: /d**e**ð̞i/ → **left**, /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ → **right** ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](img/albareda-1.png) ::: ::: ## (Bilingual) perceptual narrowing **Albareda-Castellot, Pons and Sebastian-Galles (2010)** ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} **Anticipatory eye movement paradigm** Eye-tracking Can infants anticipate the trajectory of an object based on its associated speech sounds? E.g.: /d**e**ð̞i/ → **left**, /d**ɛ**ð̞i/ → **right** ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](img/albareda-2.png) ::: ::: ## Statistical learning ::: center ![@brodbeck_continuous_2020](img/speech.jpg){fig-align="center"} ::: How can infants learn new **words** in the absence of clear **word boundaries** in the **continuous speech stream**? ## Statistical learning

::: {.mono .center} [whataprettybabyyouare]{style="background: black;color: white;"} ::: ::: {.mono .center} what-a-pretty-baby-you-are ::: ::: {.mono .center} whatapre-ttyba-byyouare ::: ::: {.mono .center} whata--prettyba-by-youare ::: ::: {.mono .center} what-a-pre-tty-ba-by-you-are ::: ## Statistical learning ::: box Infants exploit **statistical regularities** to segment the continuous speech signal into discrete units. ::: ## Statistical learning ::: box Infants exploit **statistical regularities** to segment the continuous speech signal into discrete units. ::: **Saffran, Aslin, and Newport (1996)**

::: {.columns} ::: {.column} Transitional probabilites (TP) : Relative number of co-ocurrences between two syllables ::: ::: {.column} $$ Y|X = \frac{\text{frequency of }XY}{\text{frequency of }X} $$ ::: ::: ## Statistical learning

::: {.mono .center} $TP_{pre|a} < TP_{tty|pre}$ ::: ::: {.mono .center} $TP_{tty|pre} > TP_{ba|tty}$ ::: ## Statistical learning

Can /s/ and /l/ go together in... * **Catalan** → ?? ## Phonotactics Rules governing the possible **phoneme sequences** in a (particular) language. Can /s/ and /l/ go together in... * **Catalan** → ?? * **English** → ## Phonotactics Rules governing the possible **phoneme sequences** in a (particular) language. Can /s/ and /l/ go together in... * **Catalan** → ?? * **English** → *slow* /sləʊ/ ## Phonotactics ::: box From 9 months of age, infants show sensitivity to phonotactics in their native language. ::: **Friederici and Wessels (1995)** 4.5, 6 and 9 month-old Dutch native infants Three conditions, based on their phonotacticality: - **Legal** syllables (e.g., *bref*, *murt*) - **Illegal onset** syllables (e.g., *rtum*) - **Illegal coda** (e.g., *febr*) ## Phonotactics **Friederici and Wessels (1995)** 9 month-old infants (but not younger infants) looked longer to trials in which legal syllables were presented, compared to illegal syllables. ## Word acquisition ::: box Infants acquire their first words aroud 6 months of age ::: **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** ## Word acquisition **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** Auditory word recognition study using **eye-tracking** ::: center ![@bergelson_at_2012](img/bergelson-2.jpg){width="65%"} ::: ## Word acquisition **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** Auditory word recognition study using **eye-tracking** ::: center ![](img/apple-mouth.png) ::: ## Word acquisition **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** Auditory word recognition study using **eye-tracking** ::: center ![](img/cookie-eyes.png) ::: ## Word acquisition **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** Auditory word recognition study using eye-tracking ::: center ![](img/hair-banana.png) ::: ## Word acquisition **Bergelson and Swingley (2012)** ::: center ![](img/bergelson.jpeg) ::: # 12-24 months ## Vocabulary growth From 12 months of age onwards, infants' vocabulary grows at a steady rate until 18 months of age. From 12 to 24 months, it grows much faster (*vocabulary spurt*) [@frank_wordbank:_2017; @goldfield_early_1990]. ## Vocabulary growth ::: center ![@garcia-castro_bilingual_2024](img/vocabulary-1.png){width="70%"} ::: ## Vocabulary growth ::: center ![@garcia-castro_bilingual_2024](img/vocabulary-2.png){width="70%"} ::: ## (Bilingual) vocabulary growth ::: box When both languages are taken into account, bilingual todders know as many words as monolinguals. ::: **Hoff et al. (2012)** ## (Bilingual) vocabulary growth **Hoff et al. (2012)** **Vocabulary checklists** from English monolinguals and English-Spanish bilinguals in South Florida. ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ![](img/hoff-1.png) ::: ::: {.column} ![](img/hoff-2.png) ::: ::: ## Lexical development ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

In the adult lexicon, words are stored as a **network**, interconnected by their **conceptual or phonological relatedness** [@collins1975spreading] ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/loftus.png){width="60%"} ::: ::: ::: ## Lexical development ::: {.columns} ::: {.column}

In the adult lexicon, words are stored as a **network**, interconnected by their **conceptual or phonological relatedness** [@collins1975spreading] ::: ::: {.column} ::: center ![](img/luef.png) ::: ::: ::: ## Lexical development **Lexical decision task**: Is the presented word a real word in English? * Raise your **left** hand if [yes]{style="background:green;color:white;"} * Raise your **right** hand if [no]{style="background:red;color:white;"} ---

Responses are faster and more accurate when **prime** and **target** words are **semantically related** (*NURSE-DOCTOR*) compared to when no prime is presented (*XXXX*) or when they are unrelated (*BIRD-CAT*). ## Lexical development ::: box Between 18 and 21 months, words start being represented in infants' mental lexicon in association with other phonologically and semantically related word. ::: **Arias-Trejo and Plunkett (2009)** Semantic priming task, auditory word recognition. --- ::: center ![](img/arias-1.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-2.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-3.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-4.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-5.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-6.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-7.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-8.png) ::: --- ::: center ![](img/arias-9.png) ::: ## Lexical development **Arias-Trejo and Plunkett (2009)** ::: center ![](img/arias-10.png){width="70%"} ::: # Questions ## Recap ::: incremental * Can you provide a reasonable definition of language? * Can you describe the main linguistic units? * What features of language are fetuses familarized with? * Can newborns discriminate between different languages at birth? If so, how? * Around what ages do we specialize in the phonology of our native language? Do bilinguals follow the same path as monolinguals? * When do we learn our first words? * Do we learn words at a linear rate across ages? * Does bilingualism slow down vocabulary growth? * Around what ages does the early lexicon start sharing its core features with the adult lexicon? ::: ## References
